rss.title: The Ethical Question of Marijuana
rss.subtitle: Hey Deacon John, what do you and St. Paul have in common?

subtitle_detail.value: Hey Deacon John, what do you and St. Paul have in common?

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a J-10 initiative. Hey, and welcome back to the podcast. This is Deacon John and Joe coming at you from the tree house on the third floor in Denver, Colorado. All I know is it's 40 degrees colder up here than it is now. Oh, my gosh. I kept the heater running all morning, the space heater. So if the studio bursts into flames at any moment and you hear a screaming, you know what it was. It was the space heater. Tell my parents I love them. Yeah. The. Soundboard from Hell is also with us today, and it's been shutting off randomly, so we're just hoping to get a podcast out of it. This used to happen last year, actually. We'd have to do it in under 10 minutes, otherwise the machine would just shut down. It would get bored on us or something like that. I talked to Father Mike, the old podcast guy. He's up in Craig, Colorado, as you know. He said he misses it, but he's hoping to be back in a couple weeks. He'll be down with his family for Christmastime, so we might try and kind of plug him in. A little podcast on the side, Christmas. And this is our 33rd podcast. That's right. You can say mine. You're probably around your 15th or so. Yeah. But we're doing this in honor of our friend Deacon Greg, who's going to be 33 for one more week. And then he's going to collapse into old age at age 34. So he asked us specifically to do this in honor of him. but the topic might not be the best for honoring him. And people are probably looking at this thing and saying, what does this have to do with anything Catholic, and why are you talking about it? Oh, I can think of it. Did Greg have any experience in this area? I don't know. He actually did in college before his conversion. So the medical marijuana. is the topic of today. But not just medical marijuana, but we want to like morally appraise the act. Is it morally acceptable? Not praise, appraise. Praise, not morally praise. Morally appraise. Morally appraisal. It's early still. and see how the virtue of temperance ties into that appraisal. Very cool. So why are we talking about marijuana exactly as far as Catholic podcasts? Well, here's why. It's a phenomenon in the United States. And here's, so I've got to give you just a little background information because this is affecting Catholics. And in so much as Catholics struggle with this as a substance, as a temptation, then... then the Catholic faith would have something to speak to it regarding morality. Now, Jesus didn't say, you know, in 2010 there's going to be this drug and such and such, and this is what it is. But he gave us principles by which to, you know, have a strong understanding of the moral life, and that's what we're going to get to. But that makes it complicated. But this is an issue that's a really hot topic. Very cool. Just so people know, too, it's more of an issue for us in our media experience, too, because in Colorado recently medical marijuana has been, I don't know, sanctioned or approved like it's a very common thing you can walk in downtown denver and smell marijuana and it's a legal thing and it's kind of crazy it's kind of scary it's but there's just a lot of confusion about like well is this really is this really wrong i mean and what are the other than just kind of being arbitrary like well you know it's just part of a culture that we don't like or we don't approve of you But, I mean, what's the real ethical, moral issue? Exactly. And this is good to know. It is. I hope it's going to be a little intense. I think we're going to get into it here. But it's much more complicated than we just think. We can't just be like, it's all bad. It's not that simple. And actually, the reason for this podcast is my buddy, who's a priest up in Boulder, or was, Father Peter and I were talking about it, and he wanted to know. kind of what happened, what's going on with this. And so that's what led to this study and I ended up writing a paper on this thing. So now I'm just going to read you the paper. Just joking. Okay. This began in 1996. California Ballot Initiative 215 passed it saying that the possession and cultivation of medical marijuana was legal in the state of California. Since then, 14 states have passed that. So, 15 or 14 states, now it's legal to possess marijuana for medical purposes. And that's why these dispensers are popping up. And in October of 2010, it became legal here in Colorado. And now there's more in one year, right? There's more medical marijuana dispensaries than Starbucks. That's true. I was just going to say that, but I was like, I don't know if that's actually true. It's very true. And there are nearly 1,000 applicants every day, new applicants for medical marijuana. In Colorado or in the States? In Colorado alone. Wow. In Denver alone. And this is becoming a huge crop because now they're growing it, especially in California. But it's a $14 billion. crop projected for next year. So this is a huge... I don't know if I'm able to share that too. That sounds like a lot of money. $14 billion. Now, this morning, I noticed you coughed once during Holy Hour, which is, you know, during prayer. I cough many times. Okay, well, coughing once would be enough for you to get... a prescription for medical marijuana. So basically all you have to do is do CrossFit for a day? Exactly. Exactly. If you do some kind of stupid workout like we do where it kills you and you can't use your lungs anymore. How did you describe it? It felt like shards of glass. Shards of glass in my windpipe. That's pretty much how it felt yesterday. Now it's clearing up a little bit. That's beautiful. Thank you, CrossFit. Meditation for 8 o'clock in the morning here. Okay, so first we want to talk about, real quick, what is marijuana? and then what's the status of it, and then what does the catechism have to say about all of this, and then we're going to go into the moral act. So here we go real quick. Marijuana is derived from the hemp plant cannabis. Okay? You're like, great. But the main thing is that it's got this stuff called THC. THC. Tetrahydrocannabinoid. Tetrahydrocannabinoid. And that's what gives it the psychotropic effect. That's what gets you stoned. That's what makes it kind of crazy. So THC is what is in marijuana that's so potent and so explosive that it's so effective. and that makes you stoned, gives you this experience. Now, there is evidence that THC in marijuana has a certain therapeutic utility, so to speak, so that it doesn't heal, but it does relieve symptoms. Pain relief, appetite stimulation, you know, you want to run to Taco Bell every five minutes, and then control regarding nausea and vomiting and chemotherapy. This is being shown. This is not proven, though, by the FDA, but there is evidence for its possibility. So what you have in the United States right now is you have a new drug, not approved by the FDA, that is now illegal in the United States. Marijuana is illegal, according to the federal government, but 14 states have approved it. So you have a dual legality. What does that mean? Why is this important? For a Catholic to say, well, I don't smoke marijuana because it's against the law. Well, it's kind of against the law. It's against the law federally, and it's not against the law in 14 states. Okay, for medical purposes. Now, they tried to push it for recreational use in California this year, but surprisingly, it didn't pass. It got turned down. About 55% voted against it. So it was turned down, and I was actually really surprised that that happened. But you have a complicated situation because Catholics cannot say, I don't smoke marijuana because it's against the law. You can't really say that, and that's where we're going right now. And that's the whole reason for this project is you can't say, well, if it's illegal, I can't do it. If it is legal, then I can do it. That's a very, very simplified understanding of it, and it just doesn't work morally. That's not, so we've got to look at what is the effect and what is the intention behind these things. Does that make sense? Yeah. Okay, cool. So that's, like I said, since 1970 it's been illegal in the United States, but we cannot just say because it's illegal, therefore I don't do it. Now, let's go into the next thing. The Catechism of the Catholic Church says this. This is in paragraph 2291. It says that... Marijuana is bad. Marijuana is always bad. I'm just kidding. Well, it says that drugs... So there's two catechism paragraphs that are important. 2290 says that tobacco, alcohol, and gambling can be used in moderation. Can be used in moderation. Can be used in moderation. Therefore, they can be good. So they can be morally neutral. So having a drink. Yeah, look at you. No, you're not drinking. I hope that's coffee. I don't know what you slipped in there. But the, pretty early. I guess it's noon somewhere, right? The. saying that these things are permissible, tobacco. Now, a lot of the arguments I hear is, well, marijuana is just like tobacco or alcohol. Well, hold on a second. Technically, marijuana is a drug right now. But the problem is that in our government, the laws are being repealed, so it's not a drug anymore. The next paragraph, 2291, says that drugs are always intrinsically evil to use except for the occasional therapeutic use. So our friend... Dr. Chris Lebsack will say that they'll use different drugs. He even told me about like, excuse me, small doses of cocaine, something like that for different procedures. And that would be morally permissible because of the intention, right? We're using it for therapeutic use. So that means that it's possible for that medical marijuana can be permissible for therapeutic use. So we can't just straight up condemn it. Wait, did you say all drugs are immoral? Unless it's for... medical use yeah therapeutic use and alcohol is not a drug alcohol is not a drug according to the catechism what is i mean i just missed that i don't know if you said that what makes a drug that's the problem that's the problem what makes a drug and an arbitrary yeah so if we're getting to a point in our country where legally you can't say this is a drug or not um you know because it will we will get to a point here in five ten years will those say marijuana is not a drug um you know it's just like alcohol it's just like you can just buy it wherever you we're going that way at least out in colorado we are in boulder colorado we are um so that's the problem is it a drug and what how do you what defines a drug in that and the catechism doesn't specify here's the nepple explanation though the nepple explanation all right here we go i would say if you can use marijuana in moderation then it's not a drug but if you can't then i would constitute it a drug so like heroin, you can't use heroin in moderation. It's either like you're not using heroin or you're totally, the substance is so potent and it's so explosive that it's impossible to use it in moderation. And that's what the virtue of temperance is. The virtue of temperance moderates our desire for the passions for bodily sensual pleasures. And so we have to use temperance when we use tobacco, when we use alcohol, when we gamble, you know, these different things. That is, that is, the virtue of temperance governs those. And that's what makes it morally permissible. People walk up to me all the time and they're like, you're a priest, I didn't know you could drink. And it's like, well, you don't understand. We're not just repressing all these things. We're trying to have self-mastery over our desires. And if you can't have self-mastery over something, then it's an intrinsic evil. And it's never permissible, like, except for medical uses. And that would be very good things, right? Even very good things. So if you can't, if I can't control over it with my will, then, um, then it's not morally permissible. If I can't say, okay, that's enough. I stopped there and I can't do it. So the question becomes, is marijuana, if it was repealed legally and said, everything is, um, this is not, um, uh, no longer legally called a drug. Then the question becomes for the Catholic, can I use this in moderation? Can I exercise the? virtue of temperance around marijuana to this extent. Now, this is all hypothetical because it's not legal right now, so it's not permissible right now. But it could be going that direction. But I think it will go that direction. And no one said this. This is all kind of NEPL theology here that we're kind of spinning out. That's my last name if you don't know what I'm talking about. And so it's really, really tricky to see that distinction. Now, I'll tell you something, Joe, and I'll be honest here. Before my conversion, my senior year in high school, I abused marijuana. and I was addicted to it. And I would say, from experience, that it's impossible to use it in moderation. I never had an experience. And people will argue that. Potheads will probably email us and say, no way, that's crazy. So Potheads are listening to Catholic stuff. Yeah, you never know. That's true. Andrew Polito or something. That's our friend. You're going to get an email from that. Yeah. but from my experience, it's not possible to exercise the virtue of temperance over the use of marijuana because THC is so potent. Now, let me tell you one more thing about THC. When I say marijuana was so potent in high school that I couldn't use it in moderation, I couldn't exercise the virtue of temperance, even if hypothetically it would have been legal and I could have used it, well, listen to this. THC concentrations in marijuana sold on the streets. When I was in high school, it was ranging from 1% to 3% THC content. That's how potent it was, 1% to 3%. Now it's up to 7% to 10%. No way. So, I mean, we're talking the marijuana that's on the streets right now is 3% to 4% times as potent, as explosive as I was. And I'm telling you from my experience, it was impossible. So you think of like 4% times as powerful now. What would be an analogy to compare it to drinking? If it was not possible to drink in moderation, it would be like you either don't drink or when you drink, you just get drunk right away. You can't use it and not get drunk. So you're saying you couldn't smoke pot and not get stoned. Yeah, that's what I'm saying. It's like if I took one sip of alcohol and I was totally just... just wasted. Is that really how it is? Yeah. Wow, that's wild. Yeah. That's really how it is, my young, innocent friend. And so that's kind of my take on this. And like I said, this is not church teaching today. This is not even, like, you're not even going to find this in theology. This is just taking a Catholic principle, the distinction between paragraph these two paragraphs in the catechism trying to look at them and figure it out now this will be a very interesting conversation so i look forward to people uh writing in on this and giving us their thoughts because this is just like me trying to get my head around this phenomenon which is exploding which is medical marijuana and soon to be recreational marijuana So, that's kind of a long one today, and kind of complex topically, but I think does tie in in some way. Very applicable. It's awesome. I mean, it's good to know these principles because these conversations are going to come up in our lives, and we're going to be encountering this. And to be able to say something more than, well, it's just wrong. You just shouldn't do that or something. And there's really no, we need grounds for saying that, or we shouldn't say that. Yeah. Young people are not going to be satisfied when you say to them, well, it's illegal, so don't do it. and they're not going to be satisfied when you say, well, it is legal, so go ahead and do it. They need more than that. They need real intellectual substance, and there needs to be moral criteria that's more than just, you know, moralisms. This is always the fear, is that don't do it because I said so, or don't do it because the church says so. That's not how it works, and that's never how the Catholic churches work. So we've got to avoid moralisms, just reducing everything to kind of moral laws that have no, that aren't rooted in reason or something like that. So there you go. If I catch you with blitzed eyes that are all bloodshot and your shirt's covered with Taco Bell, I'm going to kind of call you aside and make you listen to this podcast again. You know I love those Crunchwrap Supremes. They're pretty good. Well, this is good, man. I feel like you've brought me out of my innocent naivety about... Marijuana. Yeah, I'm sorry. I've grown up, I'm like scandalized and grown up all at once. I don't even know what to think about myself. Yeah, so there you go. So that's the scoop with medical marijuana. But it's, and this is the one last thing I should have said earlier. So medical marijuana, possible to be morally permissible. You have to have a just cause for it, though. You can't just have like your cough and holy hour this morning. But there are other things. There's two drugs out there. One of them especially is called Marinol, which is very popular. And it's essentially THC in a pill form. So you can have the side of the effects of relieving symptoms that marijuana would give you without getting totally stoned and smoking it. So there are other options. Like if someone's listening to this and they're a Catholic and they're debating and they're really in pain. I have a friend who's like this right now, trying to deliberate kind of what to do. There are other options than just, well, just smoke marijuana. But there's an agenda and it's forcing it upon us. So anyways, that's the final word on that. Good stuff, man. That's all I got. well we'll see you guys next week and any more thoughts, suggestions, insults, comments whatever, we will take them

summarization.results: The discussion explores the moral and legal aspects of medical marijuana use from a Catholic perspective, focusing on the virtue of temperance. It delves into the complexity of the issue, considering the potency of THC, the legality of marijuana in different states, and the importance of making informed and morally permissible choices regarding its use. Alternative options like Marinol are presented as ways to alleviate symptoms without the psychoactive effects of smoking marijuana.
